Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Situation2: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Story: My phone buzzed for the third time in ten minutes, the screen lighting up with a message from my stepmother: “How was your morning? Did you eat breakfast?” I knew she expected a quick reply, maybe even a photo of my lunch, and a rundown of my day so far. That was our routine—constant, reassuring communication, a way to bridge the gap that sometimes lingered between us. But as I sat in the cramped pharmacy break room, my mind was elsewhere. The latest pharmacy newsletter was open on my lap, full of updates about new drug releases and safety alerts. I needed to stay sharp, to keep up with the changes so I could answer patients’ questions and avoid mistakes. My manager always said, “A good pharmacist never stops learning.” I felt the pressure to prove myself at work, to be the reliable professional everyone counted on. But my phone kept buzzing, and I could feel the weight of my stepmother’s expectations pulling at me. I stared at the unread messages, torn between the world waiting for me at home and the one demanding my attention here.
